turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Proposed Dams in the Kaliwa River watershed.
turn.1: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.2: In 1999 the Kaliwa Watershed, evaluated at the time as "degraded due to anthropogenic pressures", was classified as a protected area under the National Integrated Protected Areas System.
turn.3: What does the Kaliwa watershed look like?
turn.4: The terrain is generally mountainous, surrounded by slopes > 50%, consisting partly of forested hills and partly of cultivated land, with some slash and burn cultivation (kaingin) areas present.
turn.6: Its elevation is from 220 masl (meters above sea level) to 1,530 masl.
turn.7: Does it rain a lot in the watershed?
turn.8: A number of small creeks run through the lower slopes, all eventually connecting to the main river.
turn.9: Do people live in the watershed?
turn.10: The village also serves as home to the indigenous Remontado Dumagats.
turn.12: The history of projects on the Kaliwa River watershed began with the conception of the Manila Water Supply III project in November 1979 during Martial Law under Ferdinand Marcos when then-President Marcos deferred a project which would have placed a dam in the Markina River, and instructed the MWSS to look for alternative sites.
